content:
Trial-by-fire & finding good first issues is a great approach to learning while contributing "where one is currently at" education-wise.

As an alternative or supplemental approach to "trial by fire", does Rust team have any sort of "DOJO" lists of cmpsc/software eng/systems topics that would be good to "know" while helping contribute?

e.g. "memory segmentation, compiler theory, parser types, ASTs, software eng concepts, etc. "
Or even specific class recommendations, like " I took this course and it really helped me gain foundational perspectives for XYZ https://ocw.mit.edu/courses/electrical-engineering-and-computer-science/6-004-computation-structures-spring-2017/c11/c11s2/c11s2v5/ "
Example for a backend application-layer developer might look like: https://roadmap.sh/backend
I got started with http://www.craftinginterpreters.com/ and highly recommend it
it's simple enough for one person to do in a few weeks, and in-depth enough that you learn all the parts of a compiler
that said, you don't need a bunch of experience to start contributing, you can just hop right in :)
